facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 325 of 1962 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 325 of 1962. Appeal from the judgment and decree dated

facts.text: Appeal is from the judgment and decree dated August 4, 1959 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in Appeal Suit No. 489 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated August 4, 1959 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in Appeal Suit No. 489 of 1954.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on January 23, 1964 by MUDHOLKAR J.

anchor.surface_text: January 23, 1964. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by MUDHOLKAR J.--This is an appeal against

facts.text: High Court of Andhra Pradesh reduced the amount of compensation awarded to the appellants by the Subordinate Judge, Vijayawada.

anchor.surface_text: the judgment of the High Court of Andhra Pradesh by which it reduced the amount of compensation awarded to the appellants by the Subordinate Judge, Vijayawada in respect of certain lands

facts.text: Lands acquired are survey Nos. 281/2, 339/1 to 8 and 338/1 to 3, situate at a short distance from Vijayawada and alongside Vijayawada-Eluru Road.

anchor.surface_text: in respect of certain lands belonging to them which were acquired by the State. The lands in question are survey Nos. 281/2, 339/1 to 8 and 338/1 to 3 which are situate at a short distance from the town of Vijayawada and lie alongside the Vijayawada-Eluru Road.

facts.text: Land Acquisition Officer fixed Rs. 3,500 per acre for the first two survey Nos. and Rs. 4,000 per acre for the third survey number.

anchor.surface_text: The Land Acquisition Officer had fixed Rs. 3,500 per acre for the first two of these survey Nos. and Rs. 4.000 per acre for the third survey number.

facts.text: Subordinate Judge granted uniform rate of Rs. 10,000 per acre for all survey numbers.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Subordinate Judge granted a uniform rate of Rs. 10,000 per acre for the lands comprised in all the survey numbers.

facts.text: Disputes regarding entitlement to compensation for survey No. 339/1 to 3; Land Acquisition Officer made reference to Court for apportionment.

anchor.surface_text: There were some disputes with regard to the entitlement to the compensation for survey No. 339/1 to 3 and the Land Acquisition Officer, therefore, made a reference to the Court for the apportionment of the compensation amount among the various claimants.

facts.text: Six of the appellants did not accept the award of the Land Acquisition Officer and made applications in writing within time for reference.

anchor.surface_text: Six of the appellants did not accept the award of the Land Acquisition Officer and made applications in writing to him within the time allowed by law for referring the matter for determination of the Court.

facts.text: No reference was made by Land Acquisition Officer for quantum despite applications.

anchor.surface_text: It is common ground that no reference was made by the Land Acquisition Officer in pursuance of these applications.

facts.text: Court proceeded on footing that reference included quantum of compensation.

anchor.surface_text: When the matter came up before the Court it proceeded on the footing that the reference made to it by the Land Acquisition Officer was not merely limited to the apportionment of compensation but was also with respect to the amount of compensation.

facts.text: State raised no objection in Subordinate Court regarding lack of reference for quantum.

anchor.surface_text: No objection was, however, raised on behalf of the State that in the absence of any reference upon the applications of six of the appellants the Court was incompetent to deal with that matter.

facts.text: Government pleader raised question of jurisdiction in High Court appeal.

anchor.surface_text: When the matter went up before the High Court by way of an appeal from the judgment of the Subordinate Judge, the Government pleader raised the question that in the absence of a reference on the question of quantum of compensation by the Land Acquisition Officer, the Court had no jurisdiction to consider that matter at all.

facts.text: High Court negatived the jurisdiction plea but reversed Subordinate Judge's finding on compensation amount.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, though it ultimately reversed the finding of the court as to the amount of compensation, unfortunately allowed the plea to be raised before it but ultimately upon a consideration of certain decisions, negatived it.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds Subordinate Court had no jurisdiction to determine quantum of compensation.

anchor.surface_text: Disagreeing with the High Court we, therefore, hold that the Court had no jurisdiction to determine the amount of compensation and thus go behind the order of the Land Acquisition Officer.

facts.text: Appeal dismissed by Supreme Court on jurisdiction ground.

anchor.surface_text: Upon this short ground the appeal must be dismissed.

facts.text: Seven sale deeds filed: Exs. A1 to A4 by State, B1 to B3 by appellants.

anchor.surface_text: For determining the amount of compensation seven sale deeds were filed, Exs. Al to A4, on behalf of the State and B1 to B3 on behalf of the appellants.

facts.text: Sale deed Ex. A1 dated 15-2-46, extent 0-40-1/2 acs., amount 1,750 Rs., rate 4,240 Rs./acre, opposite to suit land abutting main road.

anchor.surface_text: A-1 15-2-46 0-40-1/2 1,750 4,240 Opposite to the suit land and abutting the main road.

facts.text: Sale deed Ex. A2 dated 25-8-46, extent 0-65-1/2 acs., amount 2,500 Rs., rate 3,800 Rs./acre, some distance from acquired land towards Eluru.

anchor.surface_text: A-2 25-8-46 0-65-1/2 2,500 3,800 Some distance away from the site of the acquired land towards Eluru.

facts.text: Sale deed Ex. A3 dated 9-10-46, extent 1-00, amount 4,500 Rs., rate 4,500 Rs./acre, very near acquired land.

anchor.surface_text: A-3 9-10-46 1-00 4,500 4,500 Very near the acquired land the same vendee.

facts.text: Sale deed Ex. A4 dated 9-10-46, extent 1-00, amount 4,500 Rs., rate 4,500 Rs./acre, part of same site.

anchor.surface_text: A-4 9-10-46 1-00 4,500 4,500 Part of the same site, and the vendee.

facts.text: Sale deed Ex. B1 dated 14-10-46, extent 0-70, amount 7,000 Rs., rate 10,000 Rs./acre, 5 furlongs from suit site nearer Bezwada.

anchor.surface_text: B-1 14-10-46 0-70 7,000 10,000 5 furlongs away from the suit site and nearer Bezwada.

facts.text: Sale deed Ex. B2 dated 14-2-47, extent 1-09, amount 12,000 Rs., rate 12,000 Rs./acre, just over 5 furlongs towards Bezwada.

anchor.surface_text: B-2 14-2-47 1-09 12,000 12,000 just over 5 furlongs away towards Bezwada.

facts.text: Sale deed Ex. B3 dated 24-1-46, extent 0-36, amount 1,850 Rs., rate 5,000 Rs./acre, part of same land acquired.

anchor.surface_text: B-3 24-1-46 0-36 1,850 5,000 It is a part and parcel of the same land that is sought to be acquired.

facts.text: High Court awarded compensation at Rs. 4,500 per acre based on Exs. A3 and A4.

anchor.surface_text: It has accepted Exs. A3 and A4 and on that basis awarded compensation at the rate of Rs. 4,500 per acre for all these lands.

facts.text: Supreme Court finds no substantial grounds to interfere with High Court's conclusions on merits.

anchor.surface_text: in our opinion there are no substantial grounds which would justify interference with the conclusions arrived by the High Court.

facts.text: Lands sold under A3 and A4 are parts of the same field abutting the road.

anchor.surface_text: As regards access, it is sufficient to say that they are parts of the same field which abut on the road, though the portions sold do not themselves abut on the road.

anchor.surface_text: sub-section  1  of which reads thus Any person interested who has number accepted the award may, by written application to the Collector, require that the matter be referred by the Collector for the determination of the Court, whether his objection be to the measurement of the land, the amount of the companypensation, the persons to whom it is payable, or the apportionment of the companypensation among the persons interested.

arguments.claim: In the absence of a reference on the question of quantum of compensation by the Land Acquisition Officer under Section 18, the Court had no jurisdiction to consider that matter.

anchor.surface_text: When the matter went up before the High Court by way of an appeal from the judgment of the Subordinate Judge, the Government pleader raised the question that in the absence of a reference on the question of quantum of compensation by the Land Acquisition Officer, the Court had no jurisdiction to consider that matter at all.

arguments.court_reasoning: Lack of inherent jurisdiction as statutory terms for reference under ss.12,18,19,21,30 not complied with; precedents confirm jurisdiction arises only on reference.

arguments.claim: By reason of the failure of the State to raise the plea before the Subordinate Judge as to the absence of a reference, the State must be deemed to have waived the point.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellants it was contended before the High Court that by reason of the failure of the State to raise the plea before the Subordinate Judge as to the absence of a reference the State must be deemed to have waived the point.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: of the failure of the State to raise the plea before the Subordinate Judge as to the absence of a refer- ence the State must be deemed to have waived

arguments.court_reasoning: Inherent lack of jurisdiction cannot be waived or cured by acquiescence; precedents like Nusserwanjee, Alderson, Seth Badri Prasad confirm.

arguments.claim: High Court was wrong to hold that the defect was waivable as it was not a case of inherent lack of jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court accepted this argument upon the view that this was not a case of inherent lack of jurisdiction and that the defect in the procedure was such as could be waived.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: the view of the High Court is number companyrect. Section 12 1  of the Land Acquisition Act provides that after an award is filed in the Collectors of

arguments.court_reasoning: Jurisdiction given by statute only on specified terms; non-compliance means no jurisdiction arises; distinguished Venkata Krishnayya.

arguments.claim: Land Acquisition Officer has duty under s.18 to make reference on timely applications objecting to quantum, and State ought not take advantage of officer's remissness.

anchor.surface_text: Quite clearly applications objecting to the rates at which compensation was allowed were taken in time by persons interested in the lands which were under acquisition and it was no fault of theirs that a reference was not made by the Land Acquisition officer. Indeed, whenever applications are made under s. 18 of the Land Acquisition Act, it is the duty of the Land Acquisition Officer to make a reference unless there is a valid ground for rejecting the applications such as for instance that the applications were barred by time.

arguments.claim: Jurisdiction of court arises solely on basis of reference by Collector under ss.18,19,21; s.30 reference only for apportionment does not cover quantum.

anchor.surface_text: Section 12(1) of the Land Acquisition Act provides that after an award is filed... be final and conclusive evidence... The only manner in which the finality of the award can be called into question is by resort to the provisions of s. 18... Section 19 provides for the making of a reference by the Collector... Section 21 restricts the scope... No doubt, the Land Acquisition Officer has made a reference under s. 30... but that reference was only in regard to the apportionment.

arguments.claim: Where jurisdiction given by statute only upon specified terms, those terms must be complied with; non-compliance means no jurisdiction (citing Nusserwanjee).

anchor.surface_text: This is really no mere technicality for as pointed out by the Privy Council in Nusserwanjee Pestonjee Ors. v. Meer Mynoodeen Khan... wherever jurisdiction is given by a statute and such jurisdiction is only given upon certain specified terms contained therein it is a universal principle that those terms should be complied with, in order to create and raise the jurisdiction, and if they are not complied with the jurisdiction does not arise.

arguments.claim: Absence of inherent jurisdiction cannot be waived or cured by acquiescence (citing Alderson, Seth Badri Prasad).

anchor.surface_text: This was, therefore, a case of lack of inherent jurisdiction and the failure of the State to object... cannot amount to waiver or acquiescence. Indeed, when there is an absence of inherent jurisdiction, the defect cannot be waived nor can be cured by acquiescence. In Alderson v. Palliser... where the want of jurisdiction appears on the face of the proceedings. it cannot be waived. In Seth Badri Prasad Ors. v. Seth Nagarmal...

arguments.claim: Venkata Krishnayya distinguishable as there was a reference by Collector, albeit erroneous.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has, however, based itself largely upon a decision of the Privy Council in Venkata Krishnayya Garu v. Secretary of State. In that case there was in fact a reference by the Collector to the court but that reference was made by the Collector not upon the application of the person legally entitled to compensation but by a person whose claim... In our opinion that decision is distinguishable on the short ground that whereas here there is no reference at all...

arguments.claim: Lands in Exs. A3 and A4 have no direct access to road, so undervalued compared to acquired land.

anchor.surface_text: Some argument was advanced before us to the effect that the lands comprised in the transactions represented by these documents have no direct access to the road and that, therefore, they could not have fetched a good price.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: t case the Collector had made a reference though in making it he had companymitted an error of law in that he acted upon the application of a person w

arguments.court_reasoning: Parts of same field abutting road; purchasers get right of way over unsold portion.

arguments.claim: No substantial grounds to interfere with High Court's compensation award at Rs.4500/acre based on comparable sales Exs. A3 & A4; rejects appellants' sale deeds B1-B3.

anchor.surface_text: We have, however, heard Mr. Bhimasankaram on merits and in our opinion there are no substantial grounds which would justify interference with the conclusions arrived by the High Court. For determining the amount of compensation seven sale deeds were filed... [synopsis]... Out of these sale deeds Exs. A1 and A2 were rejected... It has accepted Exs. A3 and A4... In our opinion what the High Court has said about these three exhibits, B1, B2 and B3, seems to have considerable force...

holdings.text: Disagreeing with the High Court we, therefore, hold that the Court had no jurisdiction to determine the amount of compensation and thus go behind the order of the Land Acquisition Officer.

anchor.surface_text: Disagreeing with the High Court we, therefore, hold that the Court had no jurisdiction to determine the amount of compensation and thus go behind the order of the Land Acquisition Officer.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory scheme of Land Acquisition Act ss.12,18,19,21 requires Collector to make reference on valid application for court jurisdiction over quantum; s.30 reference limited to apportionment; universal principle that statutory jurisdiction terms must be strictly complied with (Nusserwanjee precedent); s.30 does not extend to quantum.

holdings.text: This was, therefore, a case of lack of inherent jurisdiction and the failure of the State to object to the proceedings before the court on the ground of an absence of reference in so far as the determination of compensation was concerned cannot amount to waiver or acquiescence.

anchor.surface_text: This was, therefore, a case of lack of inherent jurisdiction and the failure of the State to object to the proceedings before the court on the ground of an absence of reference in so far as the determination of compensation was concerned cannot amount to waiver or acquiescence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Lack of inherent jurisdiction from non-compliance with statutory prerequisites cannot be waived or cured by acquiescence or failure to object timely (Alderson v. Palliser, Seth Badri Prasad precedents); distinguished High Court's reliance on Venkata Krishnayya where reference existed albeit erroneous.

holdings.text: in our opinion there are no substantial grounds which would justify interference with the conclusions arrived by the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: in our opinion there are no substantial grounds which would justify interference with the conclusions arrived by the High Court. For determining the amount of compensation seven sale deeds were filed, Exs. Al to A4, on behalf of the State and B1 to B3 on behalf of the appellants.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court correctly rejected appellants' sale deeds B1-B3 (antedated, distant, post-notification) and accepted State's A3-A4 (proximate, contemporaneous); comparable sales method applied considering proximity, timing relative to s.4 notification, access; no superior evidence warrants interference.

holdings.text: As regards access, it is sufficient to say that they are parts of the same field which abut on the road, though the portions sold do not themselves abut on the road. Since the lands sold under these sale deeds were part and parcel of the same field which abuts on the road those who purchased these lands would naturally obtain a right of way over the land unsold so as to have access to the road.

anchor.surface_text: As regards access, it is sufficient to say that they are parts of the same field which abut on the road, though the portions sold do not themselves abut on the road. Since the lands sold under these sale deeds were part and parcel of the same field which abuts on the road those who purchased these lands would naturally obtain a right of way over the land unsold so as to have access to the road.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purchasers of inner portions of road-abutting field acquire right of way over unsold portions for access; thus comparable to acquired land with road frontage.

holdings.text: In the circumstances we hold that the appeal is without substance.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances we hold that the appeal is without substance.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Jurisdictional defect fatal; merits also lack merit.

anchor.surface_text: In Alderson v. Palliser Anr.  2 the Court of Appeal held that where the want of jurisdiction appears on the face of the proceedings. it cannot be waived. In Seth Badri Prasad Ors. v. Seth Nagarmal and Ors.   3  this Court has held that even the bar of illegality of a transaction though not pleaded in the courts below can be allowed to be pleaded in this Court if it appears on the face of the pleading in the case.
